summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting an in-camera conference and permission to file a renewed bail motion under seal. The attorneys argue that the motion contains sensitive personal information about sureties, financial details, and confidential discovery materials that would cause harm if made public, citing threats and harassment against Maxwell and her associates.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Cohen & Gresser, seeking renewed bail in her criminal case for sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this letter is addressed regarding bail procedures.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, co-signer of this letter requesting sealed filing of bail motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, co-signer of this letter requesting sealed filing of bail motion.

connections.description: Cohen is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this bail motion request on her behalf.
Everdell is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this bail motion request on her behalf.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and will decide on the bail motion.

events.title: Request for Sealed Bail Motion Filing
events.description: Maxwell's defense attorneys file a letter requesting permission to file a renewed bail motion under seal and an in-camera conference to discuss confidentiality procedures.

locations: 800 Third Avenue, 21st Floor, New York, New York 10022
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is preparing a renewed motion for release on bail with new information and sureties not available at the initial hearing.
The defense wants to file portions of the bail motion under seal to protect sureties' identities, Maxwell's financial details (2015-2020), and confidential discovery materials.
The letter cites specific social media threats against Maxwell, including violent posts calling for her death, as justification for keeping sureties' identities confidential.
The government consents to sealing certain information but does not consent to holding an in-camera conference as requested by the defense.
The defense references a similar case (United States v. Nejad/Sadr) where Judge Carter ordered redaction of bail materials containing sensitive private information.
